summary: An FBI lead sheet from Miami Division to Los Angeles Division requesting an interview with Michael Friedman and an unnamed individual (likely his spouse) regarding their employment with Jeffrey Epstein. The document also summarizes the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez, Epstein's former house manager, for attempting to sell victim information.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Previous house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of an obstruction of justice case for attempting to sell lists of additional Epstein victims to an undercover employee for $50,000 after being deposed in civil litigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Accused, subject of child prostitution investigation
persons.context: The central figure in a child prostitution case; pled guilty to state offenses in Florida, served prison time and community supervision, and was the employer of Rodriguez, Michael Friedman, and an unnamed individual.

persons.name: Bradley Edwards
persons.role: Attorney representing several of Epstein's victims
persons.context: Deposed Alfredo Rodriguez during the civil discovery process; was later contacted by Rodriguez who offered to sell additional victim information.

persons.name: Michael Friedman
persons.role: Former housekeeper or property manager for Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Identified as a potential witness who may have observed Epstein's interactions with underage girls; FBI requests an interview with him and an unnamed associate in La Quinta, California.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the previous house manager and butler to Epstein.
Rodriguez was deposed by Edwards, who represented Epstein's victims, and later contacted Edwards to offer victim information for sale.
Friedman previously worked for Epstein as a housekeeper or property manager at one of his properties.
Both were employees of Jeffrey Epstein, though the document does not specify direct interaction.

events.title: FBI Investigation of Epstein Begins
events.description: Miami Division began investigating Jeffrey Epstein for child prostitution, involving underage girls brought to his home for massages and sex acts.

events.title: Obstruction Case Opened Against Rodriguez
events.description: Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez for attempting to sell victim information.

events.title: Rodriguez Attempts to Sell Information
events.description: Rodriguez attempted to sell lists of additional Epstein victims to an undercover employee (UCE) for $50,000.

events.title: Epstein Completes Community Supervision
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein completed his state-mandated community supervision as a registered sex offender.

events.title: FBI Requests Interview of Michael Friedman
events.description: FBI Miami requested the Palm Springs RA to interview Michael Friedman and an associate regarding their employment with Epstein and potential witness observations.

keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Epstein's former house manager, was charged with obstruction of justice for attempting to sell lists of additional Epstein victims to an undercover employee for $50,000 in November 2009.
The FBI sought to interview Michael Friedman and an unnamed associate in La Quinta, CA, who were former Epstein employees and potential witnesses to his interactions with underage girls.

Jeffrey Epstein's criminal case resulted in a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office, leading to a guilty plea to state offenses in Florida, prison time, and sex offender registration.
Epstein maintained residences in multiple international locations including New York, Palm Beach, the U.S. Virgin Islands, New Mexico, London, and Paris.
The document indicates ongoing FBI investigative activity into Epstein's network and potential witnesses as of late 2010, after Epstein had completed his sentence.
